[ 1. rājayogaprakāra]

[I. rājayogaprakāra] (h01)

cf. YSv (PT p. 831): atha rājayogaḥ || yogasvarodaye | īśvara uvāca | rājayogaṃ pravakṣyāmi śṛṇu sarvatra siddhidam | guhyādguhyataraṃ devi nānādharmaṃ parāt param rājayogena deveśi nṛpapūjyo bhaven naraḥ | rājayogī cirāyuś ca aṣṭaiśvaryamayo bhavet ||śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ// atha rājayogaprakāro likhyate/ rājayogasyedaṃ phalaṃ yena rājayogenānekarājya:bhogasamaya eva anekapārthivavinodaprekṣaṇasamaya eva bahutarakālaṃ śarīrasthitir bhavati/ sa eva rājayogaḥ/ tasyaite bhedāḥ/ cf. YSv (PT p. 831): pañcadaśaprakāro 'yaṃ rājayogaḥ || kriyāyogo jñānayogaḥ karmayogo haṭhas tathā | dhyānayogo mantrayoga urayogaś ca vāsanā | rājaty etad brahmavaśīva ebhiś ca pañcadaśadhā | idānīṃ lakṣaṇañ caiṣāṃ kathayāmi śṛṇu priye | cf. Yogasiddhāntacandrikā (Ed. p. 2): nididhyāsanañ caika tānatādirūpo rājayogāparaparyāyaḥ samādhiḥ | tatsādhanaṃ tu kriyāyogaḥ, caryāyogaḥ, karmayogo, haṭhayogo, mantrayogo, jñānayogaḥ, advaitayogo, lakṣyayogo, brahmayogaḥ, śivayogaḥ, siddhiyogo, vāsanāyogo, layayogo, dhyānayogaḥ, premabhaktiyogaś ca |kriyāyogaḥ 1// jñānayogaḥ 2// caryāyogaḥ 3// haṭhayogaḥ 4// karmayogaḥ 5// layayogaḥ 6// dhyānayogaḥ 7// mantrayogaḥ 8// lakṣyayogaḥ 9// vāsanāyogaḥ 10// śivayogaḥ 11// brahmayogaḥ 12// advaitayogaḥ 13// siddhayogaḥ 14// rājayogaḥ 15// ete pañcadaśayogāḥ// (p01_01)

śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ (ceteri) ] śrīṇeyamaḥ (P), śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ || śrīgurave namaḥ || (N1), śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ || śrīsarasvatyai namaḥ || śrīnirañjanāya namaḥ || (D), śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ || oṃ śrīniraṃjanāya || (U1)
atha rājayogaprakāro likhyate (D N1 N2) ] atha rājayogaprakāra likhyate (U1), rājayogāntargataḥ || binduyogaḥ (E), atha tattvabiṃduyogaprāraṃbhaḥ (L), atha rājayoga liṣyate (P), atha rājayoga likhyate (U2)
rājayogasyedaṃ phalaṃ (P U2) ] rājayogasya idaṃ phalaṃ (D N1 N2), om. (E L)
yogenāneka (P N1) ] °yogena aneka° (D N2 U1 U2)
prekṣaṇasamaya (ceteri) ] prekṣyaṇasamaya (U2)
eva (ceteri) ] evaṃ (U2)
rājayogaḥ (ceteri) ] rājayogas (U2)
tasyaite (P U2) ] tasya ete (ceteri)
caryāyogaḥ (ceteri) ] tvaryāyogaḥ (U1)
layayogaḥ (ceteri) ] nayayogaḥ (U2)
lakṣyayogaḥ (ceteri) ] lakṣayogaḥ (U1)
siddhayogaḥ (P U2) ] rājayogaḥ (X)
rājayogaḥ (P U2) ] siddhayogaḥ (ceteri)
ete pañcadaśayogāḥ (D N1 P U1) ] evaṃ paṃcadaśāyogā bhavaṃti (U2)

[ 2. kriyāyogasya lakṣaṇam]

[II. kriyāyogasya lakṣaṇam] (h02)

idānīṃ kriyāyogasya lakṣaṇaṃ kathyate/ (p02_01)

idānīṃ (ceteri) ] idānī (N2), atha (U2)
kriyāyogasya (ceteri) ] kriyāyogas (U2)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathayate (D), om. (U2)

\approx YSv (PT p. 831): kriyāmuktimayo (kriyāmuktir ayaṃ YK 1.209) yogaḥ sapiṇḍisiddhidāyakaḥ (sapiṇḍe YK 1.210) | yat kāromīti (karomīti YK 1.210) saṅkalpaṃ kāryārambhe manaḥ sadā ||kriyāmuktir ayaṃ yogaḥ svapiṇḍe siddhidāyakaḥ/ yaṃ yaṃ karoti kallolaṃ kāryāraṃbhe manaḥ sadā/ \approx YSv (PT p. 831): tatsāṅgācaraṇaṃ (°saṅgā° YK 1.210) kurvan kriyāyogarato bhavet |tad tat ākuñcanaṃ kurvan kriyāyogas taato bhavet// 2.1 // 02_1

kriyāmuktir a (ceteri) ] kriyāmukti (N2), kriyāmuktiḥ || (U2)
yaṃ (ceteri) ] layaṃ (N2)
siddhidāyakaḥ (ceteri) ] siddhidāyakaṃ (U2)
tad tat ] tattataḥ (D N1 N2 P), tatas tataḥ (U2), taṃ kṛtaṃ (U1)
ākuñcanaṃ ] kuñcanaṃ (D P N1 U1 U2), kūrcanaṃ (N2)
ato bhavet (P U2) ] ato bhava (D N1 N2), ato va (U1)

[ 1. Method of Rājayoga]

[I. Method of Rājayoga] Homage to the glorious Gaṇeśa. Now, the method of Rājayoga is laid down. \indent This is the fruit of Rājayoga: Through Rājayoga, the long term durability of the body arises even when there are manifold royal pleasures [and] even when there is manifold royal entertainment and spectacle.This unique definition of Rājayoga possibly alludes to the exceptionally wealthy lifestyle of Rāmacandra's audience. Indeed, this is Rājayoga. These are the varieties of this Rājayoga: 1. Kriyāyoga (``Yoga of [mental] action''); 2. Jñānayoga (``Yoga of gnosis''); 3. Caryāyoga (``Yoga of conduct'');The first three Yogas allude to the four pādas of the Śaiva āgamas; namely kriyā[pāda], caryā[pāda], yoga[padā] and jñāna[pāda], see nishvasa2015. 4. Haṭhayoga (``Yoga of force''); 5. Karmayoga (``Yoga of deeds''); 6. Layayoga (``Yoga of absorption''); 7. Dhyānayoga (``Yoga of meditation''); 8. Mantrayoga (``Yoga of Mantra''); 9. Lakṣyayoga (``Yoga of foci''); 10. Vāsanāyoga (``Yoga of mental residues''); 11. Śivayoga (``Yoga of Śiva''); 12. Brahmayoga (``Yoga of Brahman''); 13. Advaitayoga (``Yoga of non duality''); 14. Siddhayoga (``Yoga of the Siddhas''); 15. Rājayoga (``Yoga for kings'')For Rājayoga with this meaning cf. birch2014. These are the fifteen Yogas.The definitive source of the list of the fifteen Yogas presented at the beginning of the text is uncertain. Rāmacandra's text is largely based on the content and structure of the Yogasvarodaya (YSv) as quoted in ramatosana (Ed. pp. 831 858). In this text, however, the list is incomplete. YSv mentions the total amount of fifteen Yogas but names only eight subcategories of Rājayoga. Because of that, Rāmacandra might have seen the necessity to complete it. The other source he used for compiling his text is ssplonavla (SSP) which, however, does not present such a list. An almost identical list of fifteen Yogas is found in Nārāyaṇatīrtha's yogacandrika. A comparable list of twelve Yogas occurs in Sundardās's sarvangayoga. A detailed investigation of the fifteen Yogas is presented in the introduction starting from p. .

[ 2. Characteristic of Kriyāyoga]

[II Characteristic of Kriyāyoga] \indent Now, the characteristic of Kriyāyoga is described.For a comparative analysis of all Kriyāyogas within the texts containing complex Yoga taxonomies see p. et seqq. 2.1 This Yoga is liberation through [mental] action. It bestows success (siddhi) in one's own body. Whatever wave the mind creates at the commencement of an action, through constantly restraining that very [wave] Kriyāyoga arises.

= YSv (PT p. 831): kṣamāvivekavairāgyaśāntisantoṣanispṛhāḥ | etan muktiyuto yo 'sau (muktiyutaś cāsau YK 1.211) kriyāyogo nigadyate |kṣamāvivekavairāgyaṃśāntisantoṣanispṛhāḥ/ etad yuktiyuto yo'sau kriyāyogī nigadyate// 2.2 // 02_2

viveka (ceteri) ] vivekaṃ (E U2)
vairāgyaṃ (ceteri) ] vairāgya° (U1)
nispṛhāḥ (P) ] °nispṛhaḥ (D), °nispṛhā (E N1), °niṣpṛhā ||2|| (N2), °niṣpṛhī (U1), °niṣpṛhāḥ || (U2)
etad yu (E P U1) ] etat (D N1 N2 U2)
ktiyuto (ceteri) ] muktiyuto (U2)
yo'sau (N2 U1) ] yogī (D E P N1 U2)

The text of the printed Edition (E) begins here.

= YSv (PT p. 831): mātsaryaṃ mamatā māyā hiṃsā ca madagarvitā | kāmaḥ krodho bhayaṃ lajjā lobho mohas tathā 'śuciḥ (śuciḥ YK 1.212) ||mātsaryaṃ mamatā māyā hiṃsā ca madagarvatā/ kāmakrodhau bhayaṃ lajjā lobhamohau tathā'śuciḥ// 2.3 // 02_3

mātsaryaṃ (E U1 U2) ] mātsarya (D N1 P)
hiṃsā ca (E) ] hiṃsāśā (ceteri), hiṃsāḥ || (N1)
krodhau (U1 U2) ] krodha° (E N1 P), °krodho (D)
'śuciḥ (ceteri) ] śuciḥ (E N2 U2)

= YSv (PT p. 831): rāgadveṣau ghṛṇālasyaśrāntidambhakṣamābhramāḥ (ghṛṇālasyaṃ bhrāntir dambho 'kṣamā bhramaḥ YK 1.213) | yasyai tāni na vidyante kriyāyogī sa ucyate ||rāgadveṣau ghṛṇālasyaṃ bhrantir daṃbho'kṣamā bhramaḥ/ yasyaitāni na vidyante kriyāyogī sa ucyate// 2.4 // 02_4

rāgadveṣau (ceteri) ] rāgadoṣau (U1), atha dveṣo (L)
ghṛṇā (ceteri) ] ghṛnā° (N2)
bhrantir daṃbho (ceteri) ] bhrāṃtir debho (D), bhrāntitvaṃ (E), bhrāṃti daṃbha° (U1)
'kṣamā bhramaḥ (ceteri) ] mokṣam ābhramaḥ (E), kṣamī bhramaḥ (U1)
na (ceteri) ] ca (E)

The text of manuscript L begins here.

yasyāntaḥkaraṇe kṣamāvivekavairāgyaśāntisantoṣa ityādīny utpādyante sa eva bahukriyāyogī kathyate/ \approx (Yogasaṃgraha IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 1 2): lobhamohau aśucitvaṃ rāgadveṣau ālasyaṃ pāṣaṃḍitvaṃ bhrāṃtiḥ iṃdriyavikāraḥ kāmaḥ ete yasya pratidinaṃ nyunā bhavaṃti |kāpaṭyaṃ māyāvitvaṃ hiṃsā tṛṣṇā mātsaryaṃ ahaṃkāraḥ roṣo bhayaṃ lajjā lobhaḥ mohā aśucitvaṃ rāga°dveṣa// ālasyaṃ pāṣaṃḍitvaṃ bhrāntir indriyavikāraḥ kāmaḥ/ ete yasya manasi pratidinaṃ nyūnā bhavanti \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 2): sa eva kriyāyogī kathyate ||sa eva bahukriyāyogī kathyate/ (p02_02)

kṣamā (ceteri) ] kṣamāḥ (N1), kṣamā (N2), kṣamā || (D)
vivekavairāgyaśānti (ceteri) ] vivekavairāgya | śāṃti° (N1), 'vivekavairāgyāśānti° (N2), vivekavairāgya || śāṃti° (D)
santoṣa ityādīny u (ceteri) ] °santoṣādīny (E), °santoṣa ity ādīno° (L), °santoṣa ity ādīna niraṃtaram (U1), °santoṣa ity ādayo niraṃtaraṃ (U2)
tpādyante (ceteri) ] utpadyante (E), °tpādyaṃte (L), utyaṃte (U1)
bahukriyāyogī (ceteri) ] bahukriyāyogā (D)
kathyate (ceteri) ] sa kathyate (D N2), tkacyate (U2)
kāpaṭyaṃ (ceteri) ] kāpayaṃ (L), yasyāntaḥkaraṇe kapatyaṃ (N1), kāpachaṃ (U1)
māyāvitvaṃ (N1 N2) ] māyavitvaṃ (D), yāyavitvaṃ (U1), pāpātitaṃ (U2), vittaṃ (E P), vitaṃ (L)
mātsaryaṃ (ceteri) ] mātsaryam (E), mātsarya (D U1)
roṣo (B D P L N1) ] roṣaḥ (E U1), eṣo (N2)
bhayaṃ (ceteri) ] kṣayaṃ (E)
lajjā (ceteri) ] lajā (U1)
lobhaḥ (P L) ] lobha° (ceteri), om. (U2)
mohā (ceteri) ] mohaḥ (P), moha (L N2)
aśucitvaṃ (ceteri) ] aśūcitvaṃ (N2)
rāga° (ceteri) ] rāgaḥ (P), rāja° (L), om. (E)
dveṣa (L) ] dveṣaḥ (ceteri), om. (E)
ālasyaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (E)
pāṣaṃḍitvaṃ (D N1) ] pākhaṃḍitvaṃ (L U1 U2), pākhaṃḍatvaṃ (E), pārṣaḍitvaṃ (N2)
bhrāntir ] bhrāntiḥ (ceteri)
indriyavikāraḥ (ceteri) ] iṃdriyaṃ vīkāraḥ (P), itivikāraḥ (L)
kāmaḥ (ceteri) ] kāma (N2), om. (U2)
ete (ceteri) ] eta (L), rāte (U1), etate (U2)
bhavanti (ceteri) ] bhavaīti (N1)
bahukriyāyogī (ceteri) ] bahukiyāyogī (D U1 U2)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathyaṃte (U1 U2)

2.2 Patience, discrimination, equanimity, peace, modesty, desirelessness: the one endowed with these means is said to be a Kriyāyogī. 2.3 Envy, selfishness, cheating, violence, intoxication and pride, lust, anger, fear, laziness, greed, error, and impurity. 2.4 Attachment and aversion, disgust and lazyness, error, deceit, envy [and] confusion: Whoever does not experience these is called a Kriyāyogī. ``Patience, discrimination, equanimity, peace, contentment'', etc., are cultivated in his mind. He alone is called a Yogī of many actions (bahukriyāyogī)The term bahukriyāyogī is only found in the Yogatattvabindu. It seems to be a neologism of Rāmacandra since the Yogasvarodaya and Yogasaṃgraha only use the word kriyāyogī in its passage on Kriyāyoga to denote its practitioner.. Fraud, the state of being deceptive, violence, craving, envy, ego, anger, fear, shame, greed, delusion, impurity, attachment, aversion, lazyness, heterodoxy, error, agitation of the senses, sexual desire: He in whose inner organAccording to section 50 p. Rāmacandra's inner organ (antaḥkaraṇa consist of thinking mind (manas), intellect (buddhi), ego (ahaṃkāra), spirit (citta) and consciousness caitanya. these diminish from day to day, he alone is called a Yogī of many actions (bahukriyāyogī).The most notable mention of the term kriyāyoga appears in Pātañjalayogaśāstra or Yogasūtra 2.1 where it is defined as: tapaḥsvādhyāyeśvarapraṇidhānāni kriyāyogaḥ || 2.1 || ( yogasutra). According to the introduction of this sūtra in the Vyāsabhāṣya, Kriyāyoga is presented as a means how someone with a distracted mind can also attain Yoga (vyutthitacitto 'pi yogayuktaḥ). Yoga, which for Patañjali is samādhi, shall be achieved by the three elements of Kriyāyoga, namely mental, moral, and physical austerity (tapas), repetition of mantras or study of sacred literature (svadhyāya) and surrender to god (īśvarapraṇidhāna). This trinity of means is supposed to destroy the impurities (kleśas) of citta. These are given in Pātanjalayogaśāstra 2.3 as ignorance (avidyā), egoism (asmitā), attachment (rāga), aversion (dveṣa) and fear of death (abhiniveśa), see ( yogasutra). All three terms of Patañjali's Kriyāyoga are absent in the Yogatattvabindu. Nevertheless, the individual elements of the kleśas, along with the aim to reduce these in the yogi's mind, can also be found in the Yogatattvabindu. Nārāyaṇatīrtha in this commentary on the Pātanjalayogaśāstra titled Yogasiddhāntacandrikā, who, like Rāmacandra uses a very similar list of fifteen Yogas, presents Kriyāyoga as the first item of his list and explains its purpose as the generation of samādhi and the reduction of kleśas ( yogacandrika). In contrast, the Kriyāyoga of Rāmacandra leads to Rājayoga, which he conceptualizes as bringing about the steadiness of the body.Kriyāyoga is absent in Sundardās's twelvefold taxonomy of the sarvangayoga.

[ 3. rājayogasya bhedāḥ \ldots siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga mantrayogaḥ]

[III. rājayogasya bhedāḥ \ldots siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga mantrayogaḥ] (h03)

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 2 3): atha rājayogasya bhedau kathyete ||idānīṃ rājayogasya bhedāḥ kathyante/ ke te/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 3): siddhakuṃḍaliyogaḥ mantrayogaś ceti |ekaḥ siddhakuṇḍalinīyogaḥ mantrayogaḥ cf. YSv (PT p. 831): jñānayogaṃ pravakṣyāmi tajjñānī śivatāṃ vrajet | paṭhanāt smaraṇād vyānān maṇḍanāt brahmasādhakaḥ | tad bhedasyaikasandhānam aṣṭaiśvaryamayo bhavet | tritīrthaṃ yatra nāḍī ca tripuṇyaṃ parameśvari | \ldots eṣo'sya viśvarūpasya rājayogo mato budhaiḥ | viśeṣaṃ kathayiṣyāmi śṛṇu caikamanāḥ sati |amū rājayogau kathyete/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 3 4): mūlakandasthāne ekā tejomayā mahānāḍī vartate |mūlakandasthāne ekā tejorūpā mahānāḍī vartate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 831 832): mūlakande sthale caikā nāḍī tejasvatī parā (tejasvitāparā YK 1.246) | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 4): iyaṃ iḍāpiṃgalasuṣumnā bhedā tridhā | vāmabhāge caṃdrarūpā iḍā | dakṣiṇabhāge sūryarūpā piṃgalā |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): gudorddhe (gudordhve YK 1.247) sā tribhāgābhūdiḍā (tridhā bhūyādiḍāvāme YK 1.247) nāma śaśiprabhā | śaktirūpā mahānāḍī dhyānāt sarvārthadāyinī | dakṣiṇe'pi kulākhyeti (dakṣiṇe piṅgalākhyeti YK 1.248) puṃrūpā sūryavigrahā |iyam ekā nāḍī iḍāpiṅgalāsuṣumṇān// etān bhedān prāpnoti/ vāmabhāge candrarūpā iḍānāḍī vartate/ dakṣiṇabhāge sūryarūpā piṅgalānāḍī vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 5 6): madhyamārge atisūkṣmā visataṃtusamākārā koṭividyutprabhā bhuktimuktipradā suṣumnā nāḍī vartate | yasyāḥ jñāne purusaḥ sarvajño bhavati |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): madhyabhāge suṣumnākhyā brahmaviṣṇuśivātmikā | śuddhacittena sā vijñā vidyutkoṭisamaprabhā | bhuktimuktipradā dhyānād aṇimādiguṇapradā |cf. SSP 2.26 (Ed. p. 38): mūlakandād daṇḍalagnāṃ brahmanāḍīṃ śvetavarṇāṃ brahmarandhraparyantaṃ gatāṃ saṃsmaret | tanmadhye kamalatantunibhāṃ vidyutkoṭiprabhām ūrdhvagāminīṃ tāṃ mūrtiṃ manasā lakṣayet | sarvasiddhipradā bhavati |madhyamārge'tisūkṣmā padminītantusamākārā koṭividyutsamaprabhā bhuktimuktidā śivarūpiṇī suṣumṇā nāḍī pravarttate/ asyāṃ jñānotpattau satyāṃ puruṣaḥ sarvajño bhavati// (p03_01)

asyāṃ ] 'syā (E), asyā (P L U2), om. (X)
jñānotpattau (Y) ] °tpanne (X)
satyāṃ (P L U2) ] satyaṃ (E), sati (X)

[ 3. Varieties of Rājayoga \ldots Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga [and?] Mantrayoga]

[III. Varieties of Rājayoga \ldots Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga [and?] Mantrayoga] (h03)

Now, varieties of Rājayoga are described. Which are these? One is Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga and oneThe use of the term siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga instead of siddhayoga as listed initially is surprising. Furthermore, this type of Yoga, listed as the second last item in the initial Yoga taxonomy (section 1, p. ), is introduced as the second type right after Kriyāyoga, the first item in both the initial list and the subsequent text. This raises further questions as the term kuṇḍaliṇī is not mentioned at all in the subsequent description of this type of Yoga. The relation between Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga and Mantrayoga appears mysterious since only witness englishU 2 provides a description of a specific type of Mantrayoga. The additional passages of witness U2, marked in greyscale, instruct the ``recitation of the non recited'' (ajapājapa) of the haṃsaḥ mantra, also called ``non recitation'' (ajapā) Gāyatrī, during meditation for almost each (seven out of nine) cakras. All witnesses except englishL ( englishL omits the term mantrayoga) preserve this reading, and the sentence that follows the term supports the reading of mantrayoga by the usage of dual forms. The Yogatattvabindu closely follows the structure and content of the Yogasvarodaya, as quoted with reference in Prāṇatoṣiṇī and Yogakarṇikā. However, the Yoga introduced in Yogasvarodaya at this point is jñānayoga and neither siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga nor mantrayoga are mentioned. Since all manuscripts preserve this reading, but only in the context of englishU 2 the term makes some sense, one could assume the additional passages of englishU 2 might have been original but they are more likely later addtions and the question remains unresolved. The closely related sarada 25.37ab provides a possible explanation for the linking of the two types of Yoga: ``The {kuṇḍalī} Śakti abides in the haṃsaḥ [and] supports the [individual] Self.'' (bibharti kuṇḍalī śaktir ātmānaṃ haṃsaṃ āśritā |), see saradatilakafull.] is Mantrayoga. These two Rājayogas are described [in the following]. At the location of the root bulbThe root bulb or kanda in yogic literature is usually located below the navel or near the perineum. Rāmacandra's concept of the kanda is identical to the one found in vivekamartandaolda 16: ``Above the penis and below the navel is the home of the kanda, which is [formed] like the egg of a bird. There, the 72000 channels originate.'' (ūrdhvaṃ meḍhrād adho nābheḥ kandayoniḥ khagāṇḍavat | tatra nāḍyaḥ samutpannāḥ sahasrāṇi dvisaptatiḥ ||) exists one major channel in the form of light. This single channel splits up into Iḍā, Piṅgalā and Suṣumnā. On the left side is the lunar Iḍā channel. On the right side exists the solar Piṅgalā channel. Within the middle path, having the very subtle form equal to the fibre of a stalk of a lotus [and] shining like a thousand lightnings, bestowing enjoyment and liberation, [and] having the form of benevolence, the central channel occurs. After the generation of knowledge about her has arisen, the person becomes omniscient. \flushpage

[ 4. mūlacakram]

[IV. mūlacakram] (h04)

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 6): atas taj jñānotpattāv upāyā ucyaṃte |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): suṣumnāntaḥ samāśritya navacakraṃ yathā śṛṇu | mūlādhāraṃ catuṣpatraṃ gudorddhe (gudordhve YK 1.250) varttate mahat | tanmadhye svarṇapīṭhe tu trikoṇaṃ maṇḍalaṃ (trikoṇamaṇḍalaṃ YK 1.251) param | tatra vahniśikhākārā mūrttiḥ sarvatra siddhidā | asyā dhyānaṃ manomadhye vinā pīṭhena (pāṭhena YK 1.252) vāṅmayam | sarvaśāstrāṇi saṅkarṣaṃ (saṃkarṣa YK 1.252) sadā sphurati yogavit |cf. SSP 2.1 (Ed. p. 29): piṇḍe navacakrāṇi | ādhāre brahmacakraṃ tridhāvartaṃ bhagamaṇḍalākāram | tatra mūlakandaḥ | tatra śaktiṃ pāvakākārāṃ dhyāyet | tatraiva kāmarūpapīṭhaṃ sarvakāmaphalapradaṃ bhavati |idānīṃ suṣumṇāyāḥ jñānotpattāv upāyāḥ kathyante/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): gudamūlacakraṃ caturdalaṃ |ādau caturdalaṃ mūlacakraṃ vartate/ prathamaṃ ādhāracakram/ gudā sthānam// raktavarṇam// gaṇeśaṃ daivatam// siddhibuddhiśaktim// muṣako vāhanam// kurmaṛṣiḥ// ākuñcanamudrā// apānavāyuḥ// ūrmī kalā// ojasvinī dhāraṇā// caturdaleṣu rajaḥsattvatamomanāṃsi// vaṃ śaṃ ṣaṃ saṃ// madhyatrikoṇe triśikhā// tanmadhye \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): tanmadhye trikoṇākāraṃ kāmapiṭhaṃ |trikoṇākāraṃ kāmapiṭhaṃ vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): tatpīṭhamadhye agniśikhākārā gaṇeśamūrttir varttate |tatpīṭhamadhye 'gniśikhākāraikā murtir vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 8 9): tasyā mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt sakalakāvyanāṭakādisakalavāṅmayaṃ vinābhyāsena puruṣasya manomadhye sphurati |tasyāḥ mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt śāstrakāvyanāṭakādisakalavāṅmayaṃ vinābhyāsena puruṣasya manomadhye sphurati/ asya bahir ānandaḥ// yogānandaḥ// vīrānandaḥ// uparamānandaḥ// ajapājapaśat// 600// ghaṭi 1 palāni 40// (p04_01)

suṣumṇāyāḥ (D N1 N2) ] suṣumṇāyāṃ (E), suṣumṇāyā (P U2), suṣumnāya° (U1), suṣumnā° (L)

kathyante (ceteri) ] kathyate (L)

[ 4. Cakra of the root]

[IV. Cakra of the root (h04)

Now, the means for the genesis of knowledge of the central channel are described. At the beginning [of the central channel] exists the four petalled root cakra. The first is the adhāracakra.This term already occurs in the tenfold cakra system of the 13th c. samgitaratna 2.120ab. The location is the anus. The color is red. The deity is Gaṇeśa. The power is success and intelligence. The mount is a rat. The Ṛṣi is Kūrma. The seal is contraction. The vitalwind is Apāna. The digit is Ūrmi. The concentration is Ojasvinī. In the four petals [exists] rajas, sattva, tamas and the mind faculties; [as well as] vaṃ śaṃ ṣaṃ and saṃ. A trident is [situated] in the internal triangle. In its middle is kāmapīṭhaThis refers to one of the four pīṭhas of tantric Buddhism and the Kaula Yoginī Tantra named Kāmarūpa, specifically the present day Kāmākhyā Temple in Assam, which is located at different parts of the yogic body in various yoga traditions. For an in depth discussion of the term, see liersch2023, rosati2020 and asiddhi. The Śārṅgadharapaddhati, Śivayogapradīpikā and Siddhasiddhāntapaddhati (all texts teach a ninefold cakra system) place Kāmarūpa at the brahmacakra. in the shape of a triangle. In the middle of this seat (pīṭha) exists a single manifestation in the shape of a flame of fire. As a result of meditation on this manifestation, any literature, [such as] śāstras, poetry, drama, etc., appears in the person's mind without learning. [Assigned to it are] external bliss, yogic bliss, heroic bliss [and] the bliss of coming to restThe 11th c. Amanaska, the earliest text on Rājayoga, also mentions various blisses such as ānanda, paramānanda, sahajānanda, and cinmātrānanda throughout the text ( birch2013). The association of four similar blisses (paramānanda, sahajānanda, vīrānanda and yogānanda.) with the first cakra at the anus is found in the 13th c. samgitaratna (2.120cd 2.121ab) of Śārṅgadeva. Earlier references to the ``four blisses'' are found in Vajrayāna sexual yoga (cf. isaac2014 and sferra2000). The hevajra (1.1.28 et passim) lists ānanda, paramānanda, sahajānanda, and viramānanda. The latter, known as the "Bliss of Cessation," relates to male pleasure during sexual ritual ejaculation. These concepts were later incorporated into the asiddhi. However, the asiddhi contrasts sexual ritual with the celibate yoga of male ascetics, who abstain from sexual intercourse. In 7.4, the text asserts semen (bindu) as the source of "the Blisses whose last is Virama," and in 34.3, it claims that accomplished yogins enjoy the three ānandas (likely ānanda, paramānanda, and sahajānanda) without ejaculation, reflecting the taught celibate yoga (cf. asiddhi). Later texts, including the Amaraughaprabodha, which cite the Amṛtasiddhi, altered or removed Buddhist specific concepts, such as Vajrayāna sexual yoga terminology ( birch2019).. A hundredfold recitation of the non recited: 600. 1 ghaṭi [and] 40 palas.See p. note ghatinote for an explanation of the units of measurement.

[ 5. svādhiṣṭhānacakram]

V. svādhiṣṭhānacakram] (h05)

cf. SSP 2.2 (Ed. p. 28): dvitīyaṃ svādhiṣṭhānacakram | tanmadhye paścimābhimukhaṃ liṅgaṃ pravālāṅkurasadṛśaṃ dhyāyet | tatraivoḍyānapīṭhaṃ jagadākarṣaṇaṃ bhavati | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 9 11): liṃgo dvitīyaṃ ṣaṭdalaṃ svādhiṣṭānasaṃjñakaṃ kamalaṃ udyānapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ vartate | tatra atiraktaṃ yahbhā saṃjñakaṃ tejaḥ | tasyā nāt sādhakaḥ atisuṃdarāṃgasan yuvatīnām ativallabhaḥ san pratidinam āyuṣyābhivṛddhimān bhavati | cha |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): liṅgamūle tu pīṭhābhaṃ (raktābhaṃ YK 1.253) svādhiṣṭhānan tu ṣaḍdalam | tanmadhye bālasūryābhaṃ mahajjyotiḥ susiddhidam | dhyānāc ca varddhate āyuḥ kandarpasamatāṃ vrajet |idānīṃ dvitīyaṃ svādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ ṣaṭdalaṃ uḍḍīyāṇapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ bhavati/ liṅgasthānam// pītavarṇam// pītaprabhā// rajo guṇaḥ// brahmā devatā// vaikharī vāca// sāvitrī śaktiḥ// haṃsavāhanam// vahaṇa ṛṣiḥ// kāmāgniprabhā// sthūladehaḥ// jāgrad avasthā// ṛgvedaḥ// ācāryaliṅgam// brahmasalokatā mokṣaḥ// śuddhabhūmikā tattvam// gandho viṣayaḥ// apānavāyuḥ// antarmātṛkāḥ// vaṃ bhaṃ maṃ yaṃ raṃ laṃ// bahirmātṛkāḥ// kāmā// kāmākhyā// tejasvinī// ceṣṭikā// alasā// mithunā// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 6000 // gha. 16 pa. 40// tanmadhye'tiraktavarṇaṃ tejo vartate/ tasya dhyānāt sādhako'tisundaro bhavati/ yuvatīnāṃ ativallabho bhavati/ pratidinam āyur vardhate// (p05_01)

idānīṃ (ceteri) ] idānī (N2)
dvitīyaṃ (ceteri) ] dvitīye (U2)
svādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ (U1) ] svādhiṣṭānacakraṃ (D E L P N1 U2), svādhinacakraṃ (N2)
ṣaṭdalaṃ (ceteri) ] ṣaḍdalaṃ (E), ṣaḍḍalaṃ (N2)
uḍḍīyāṇapīṭha (U2) ] upāyanapīṭha° (E), uḍḍīyān pīṭhaṃ (L), uḍyānapīṭha° (N1 N2), uḍyāṇāpīṭha° (D), uḍāganapīṭa° (U1)
guṇaḥ ] guṇa (U2)
sthūladehaḥ ] sthūladehā (U2)
ṛgvedaḥ ] ṛg veda (U2)
śuddhabhūmikā ] śuddhabhumikā (U2)
antarmātṛkāḥ ] antarmātṛkā (U2)
bahirmātṛkāḥ ] bahirmātrā (U2)

dhako (E P L U2) ] sādhakaḥ (ceteri)
'tisundaro (Y) ] atisuṃdaro (X)
yuvatīnāṃ ativallabho bhavati (N2) ] om. (ceteri)
pratidinam ā (Y) ] dinaṃ dinaṃ prati (N1 U1), dinadinaṃ prati (N2), dinaṃ prati (D)

[ 5. Svādhiṣṭānacakra]

[V. Svādhiṣṭānacakra] (h05)

Now, the second is the six petalled Svādhiṣṭhānacakra known as the seat of UḍḍīyāṇaThe term uḍḍīyāṇa originally refers to one of the four pīṭhas of tantric Buddhism and the Kaula Yoginī Tantra, see white1996. According to kowski1988 (1988), sandersonshaivaexe (2007) and urban2010, Uḍḍiyāna is probably situated in the Swat Valley in modern Pakistan. See sandersonshaivaexe for a detailed term discussion. Throughout the text corpus of Haṭhayoga, the pīṭhas are repeatedly located differently in the yogic body. Additionally, the term refers to a certain yogic technique classified as mudrā and termed uḍḍiyānabandha which usually involves a specific type of muscular contraction around the location of the navel. For a detailled discussion of practice see rootsofyoga2017. The location is the penis. The colour is yellow. The shine is yellow. The quality is Rajas. The deity is Brahmā. The speech is Vaikharī. The power is Sāvitrī. The mount is a goose. The Ṛṣi is Vahaṇa. The appearance is Kāmāgni. Thee body is gross. The state is waking. Ṛg is the Veda. The object of veneration (liṅga) is the teacher. The liberation is Brahmasalokatā (``Residing in the world of Brahmā''). The principle is pure earth. The sense object is smell. The vitalwind is Apāna. The internal syllables [are]:In all instances where englishU 2 provides the inner (antar°) syllables and outer (bahir°) mother goddesses, I have corrected and standardized all occurrences of °mātrā or °mātrāḥ to the appropriate word and form, which is °mātṛkāḥ. This emended form, °mātṛkāḥ, on one hand, conveys a clearer meaning when applied to syllables placed on the cakras, while also signifying "mothers" or "mother goddesses," precisely as presented in all cases where englishU 2 provides bahirmātṛkā. In any case englishU 2 yields a list of goddesses in the nominative singular feminine. Furthermore, this decision is reinforced by evidence from other texts. For example, in Agasthyamuni's rajayoga (fol. 8 9), nearly identical syllable combinations are placed on the petals of the cakras within its sixfold cakra system (antarmātṛkā nyāsaprakāraḥ maṃ mūlādhāre caturdalakrameṇa vinyasya oṃ vaṃ namaḥ | oṃ śaṃ namaḥ | oṃ ṣaṃ namaḥ | oṃ saṃ namaḥ | iti mūlādhāramaṇḍape vinyasya | svādhiṣṭhāne nābhyadhasthapadmeṣu ṣaṭsudaleṣu | oṃ bhaṃ namaḥ | oṃ maṃ namaḥ | oṃ yaṃ namaḥ | oṃ raṃ namaḥ | oṃ laṃ namaḥ | iti ṣaṭsu daleṣu vinyasya |) vaṃ bhaṃ maṃ yaṃ raṃ laṃ. The external mother goddesses [are]: Kāmā, Kāmākhyā, Tejasvinī, Ceṣṭikā, Alasā [and] Mithunā.The worship of mothers is originally a central element of the Śākta tradition known as Kaula Śivaism. It belongs to the Mantramārga and developed from the former Kāpālika cult. See oberlies2012 2012, p. 92. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palas. In its middle exists an extremely red light. The adept becomes very handsome as a result of meditation on it. He becomes one whom young women desire. His lifespan increases every day. \flushpage

[ 6. nābhisthāne padmam]

[VI. nābhisthāne padmam] (h06)

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): tṛtīyaṃ nābhideśe tu digdalaṃ paramādbhutam | mahāmeghaprabhaṃ tat tu koṭividyutsamanvitam | kalpāntāgnisamaṃ (kalpānto 'gni° YK 1.255) jyotis tanmadhye saṃsthitaṃ svayam | tasya (asya YK 1.256) dhyānāc cirāyuḥ syād arogo (arogī YK 1.256) jagatāṃ varaḥ (jagatāmvaraḥ YK 1.256) | sarvapāpavinirmukto jagatkṣobhakaro (jaganmokṣakaro YK 1.256) mahān |cf. SSP 2.3 (Ed. p. 30): tṛtīyaṃ nābhicakraṃ pañcāvartaṃ sarpavat kuṇḍalākāram | tanmadhye kuṇḍalinīṃ śaktiṃ bālārkakoṭisannibhāṃ dhyāyet | sā madhyā śaktiḥ sarvasiddhidā bhavati |Yogasaṃgraha IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 11: nābhistnāne daśadalaṃ cakraṃ |tṛtīyaṃ nābhisthāne daśadalaṃ padmaṃ vartate/ kapilavarṇam// viṣṇudevatā// lakṣmī śaktiḥ// āyu ṛṣiḥ// samānavāyuḥ// garuḍavāhanam// sūkṣmaliṅgaṃ dehaḥ// svapnāvasthā// madhyamā vāk// yajur vedaḥ// dakṣiṇo'gniḥ// samīpatā mokṣaḥ// guruliṅgaviṣṇuḥ// āpas tattvam// raso viṣayaḥ// daśadalāni// daśamātṛkāḥ antarmātṛkāḥ// ḍaṃ ḍhaṃ ṇaṃ taṃ thaṃ daṃ dhaṃ naṃ paṃ phaṃ// bahirmātṛkāḥ// śāntiḥ// kṣamā// medhā// tanayā// medhāvinī// puṣkarā// haṃsagamanā// lakṣyā// tanmayā// amṛtā// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 6000// gha. 16 pa. 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 11 2v. ll. 1): tanmadhye paṃcakoṇaṃ pīṭhe lakṣmīnāparvatī saṃjñakaṃ guṇā sahitā śiva saṃjñakā rāmaṇaṃ rūpātanmadhye pancakoṇaṃ cakraṃ vartate/ tanmadhye ekā mūrtir vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll.1 2): yasyās tejo jihvayā kathituṃ na śakyate tasā dhyānakaraṇāt sādhakasya śarīraṃ sthiraṃ bhavati |cha|tasyās tejo jihvayā kathayituṃ na śakyate/ tasyāḥ mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt pupuruṣasya śarīraṃ sthiraṃ bhavati// (p06_01)

tṛtīyaṃ (ceteri) ] tṛtīye (E), atha tṛtīyaṃ maṇipūracakraṃ (U2), tṛtīyacakraṃ (N2)
daśadalaṃ (ceteri) ] daśadala° (L), daśadalakaṃ (U1), om. (U2)
padmaṃ (E P U1) ] °padme (L), padma (D N1 N2), om. (U2)
vartate (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
āyu ] vayu (U2)
sūkṣmaliṅgaṃ dehaḥ ] sūkṣmaliṅgadevatāha (U2)
dakṣiṇo'gniḥ ] dakṣināgniḥ (U2)
samīpatā ] samipatā (U2)
raso ] rajo (U2)
daśamātṛkāḥ ] daśamātrāḥ (U2)
antarmātṛkāḥ ] antarmātrā (U2)
bahirmātṛkāḥ ] bahirmātrā (U2)
haṃsagamanā ] ahaṃsagamanā (U2)
sahasraḥ ] sahasra (U2)
tanmadhye pancakoṇaṃ cakraṃ vartate (ceteri) ] om. (L)
tanmadhye (ceteri) ] om. (L)
ekā (ceteri) ] om. (L)
mūrtir va (ceteri) ] om. (L)
rtate (ceteri) ] asmi (U2)
tasyās te (Y U1) ] tasyā (D N1 N2)
kathayituṃ (ceteri) ] kathyituṃ (L), kathatuṃ (U1), vaktuṃ (U2)
tasyāḥ (X E U2) ] tasyā (P L)
mūrter dhyā (ceteri) ] mūrtir (L), om. (U2)
karaṇāt pu (ceteri) ] karaṇāt || (L), °kāraṇāt (E)
puruṣasya (ceteri) ] om. (P)
śarīraṃ (ceteri) ] om. (P)
sthiraṃ (ceteri) ] om. (P)
bhavati (ceteri) ] bhavati vā (U1), om. (P)

[ 6. Lotus within the place of the navel]

[VI. Lotus within the place of the navel] (h06)

The third ten petalled lotus exists at the location of the navel. The color is red. The deity is Viṣṇu. The power is Lakṣmī. The Ṛṣi is Āyu .The name vayu for a ṛṣi as attested in manuscript englishU 2 is probably a mistake. Since immediately afterwards the associated vāyu is given this should be an eyeskip. My best guess is āyu, the name of a sage mentioned in rigveda 2,14,7 and rigvedaglossar, p. 24. The vitalwind is Samāna. The mount is Garuḍa. The body is the subtle body.I corrected devatāha to dehaḥ since a deity was mentioned before, sūkṣmaliṅgaṃ most likely refers to a deha and, as in the second cakra the deha is followed by an avasthā. The state is sleep. The speech is Madhyamā. The Veda is Yajur. The fire is the southern [fire]. The liberation is Samīpatā. The guruliṅgaFor the phallus of Śiva, considered as one’s teacher or guide, cf. shivapura 1.18.31. is Viṣṇu. The principle is Water. The sense object is taste.I emended rajo to raso since the association of water with taste is well known. There are ten petals [and] ten mātṛkas. [The] internal syllables [are]: ḍaṃ ṭaṃ ṇaṃ taṃ thaṃ daṃ dhaṃ naṃ paṃ phaṃ. The external mother goddesses [are]: Śānti, Kṣamā, Medhā, Tanayā, Medhavinī, Puṣkarā, Haṃsagamanā, Lakṣyā, Tanmayā and Amṛtā.The bīja series under consideration adheres to the standardised conventions of the six cakra systems of the second millennium, as is evident from its widespread use. Regarding the bahirmātṛkāḥ of englishU 2 I was not able to find parallel lists in other texts. A thorough investigation for co occurrence in my electronic text library did not reveal any such instances. The tradition of associating deities with the cakra petals or series of syllables is well documented, as seen in the Rudrayāmala Uttaratantra, with historical roots that can be traced back to the kubjika, albeit with different enumerations. The conventional practice of juxtaposing antarmātṛkānyāsa and bahirmātṛkānyāsa is prevalent and denotes the internal implantation of syllables into the cakras, followed by the reinforcement of the outer body by the same alphabetic bījas. This concept is further elaborated in texts such as the Dīpikā on the Nitāṣoḍaśikārṇava and the Śāradātilaka. I want to thank Shaman Hatley for answering my questions regarding this subject. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palas.Thus, the prescribed duration for meditation on this cakra is six hours and fourty minutes. In its middle exists a cakra with five angles. In the middle of it is a single manifestation. It is not possible to describe the splendour of it with speech. As a result of meditation on this manifestation, the body of the person becomes durableThe source text specifies this bodily durability as a long lifespan (cirāyuḥ) and freedom from diseases (aroga)..In comparison to the previous svādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ this cakra at the navel is not associated with a guṇa, a dhāraṇā, a prabhā and a mudrā. \flushpage

[ 7. hṛdayamadhye kamalam]

[VII. hṛdayamadhye kamalam] (h07)

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): anāhatam aṣṭapīṭhaṃ (mahāpīṭhaṃ YK 1.257) caturthakamalaṃ hṛdi | sūryapatraṃ mahājyotir mahāsūkṣman tu cākṣuṣam | sūryapatraṃ dvādaśadalam (sentence om.in YK) | tanmadhye'ṣṭadalaṃ padmam ūrddhavaktraṃ mahāprabham | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 2): hṛdayamadhye dvadaśadalaṃcf. SSP 2.4 (Ed. p. 30): caturthaṃ hṛdayacakram aṣṭadalakamalam adhomukhaṃ tanmadhye karṇikāyāṃ liṅgākārāṃ jyotīrūpām dhyāyet | saiva haṃsakalā sarvendriyavaśyā bhavati |caturthaṃ hṛdayamadhye dvādaśadalaṃ kamalaṃ vartate/ anāhatacakraṃ hṛdayasthānam// śvetavarṇam// tamo guṇaḥ// rudro devatā// umā śaktiḥ// hiraṇyagarbha ṛṣiḥ// nandī vāhanam// prāṇavāyuḥ// jyotiskalākāraṇaṃ deham// suṣuptir avasthā// paśyantī vācā// sāmavedaḥ// gārhapatyo'gniḥ// śivaliṅgam// prāptibhūmikā// sarūpatā muktiḥ// dvādaśadalāni// dvādaśamātṛkāḥ// kaṃ khaṃ gaṃ ghaṃ ṅaṃ caṃ chaṃ jaṃ jhaṃ ñaṃ ṭaṃ ṭhaṃ// bahirmātṛkāḥ// rudrāṇī// tejasā// tāpinī// sukhadā// caitanyā// śivadā// śāntiḥ// umā// gaurī// mātarā// jvālā// prajvālinī// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 6000// gha. 16 pa. 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 2): tejomayatvāt | dṛṣṭigocaraṃ na bhavaty etādṛśaṃ vartate |atitejomayatvād dṛṣṭigocaraṃ na bhavati/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 3): tanmadhye 'ṣṭadalaṃ adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ ||tanmadhye'ṣṭadalam am adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ vartate/ manaś cakre// mano devatā// bahiś śaktiḥ// ātmā ṛṣiḥ// hṛdayamadhye sthitaṃ padmaṃ nālaṃ tasya daśāṅgulaṃ/ komalaṃ tasya tan nālaṃ/ nirmalaṃ cāpy adhomukhaṃ/ kadalīpuṣpasaṃkāśaṃ tanmadhye ca pratiṣṭhitaṃ/ mana unnatiḥ saṃkalpaṃ vikalpātmakam eva ca/ pūrvadale śvetavarṇe yadā viśramate manaḥ dharmakīrtividyādisadbuddhir bhavati/ agnikoṇe āraktavarṇe nidrālasyamāyāmandamatir bhavati/ dakṣiṇe kṛṣṇavarṇeti tadā krodhotpattir bhavati/ nairṛtye nīlavarṇe mamatāmatir bhavati/ paścime kapilavarṇe krīḍāhāsotsavotsāhamatir bhavati/ vāyavye śyāmavarṇe cintodvegamatir bhavati/ (p07_01)

caturthaṃ (ceteri) ] caturthacakrakamalaṃ (N2)
kamalaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (N2)
vartate (ceteri) ] asti (U2), bhavati (N2)

jyotiskalākāraṇaṃ deham ] jyotiḥ kalākāraṇaṃ dehe (U2)
paśyantī ] paśyaṃti (U2)

'ṣṭadalam a (E U2) ] 'ṣṭadale (P), ṣṭadalaṃ (L), aṣṭadalaṃ (X)
m adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ (ceteri) ] adhomukhakamalaṃ (L), mukhaṃ kamalaṃ (P)
vartate (ceteri) ] asti (U2)
bahiś śaktiḥ ] bahiśaktiḥ (U2)
ātmā ] ātma° (U2)
hṛdayamadhye ] nābhimadhye (U2)
daśāṅgulaṃ ] daśāgulaṃ (U2)
unnatiḥ ] unnaty (U2)
saṃkalpaṃ ] asaṃkalpa (U2)
śveta ] sveta° (U2)
viśramate ] viśrāmate (U2)
nidrālasya ] nidrā ālasya° (U2)
nairṛtye ] naiṛtye (U2)
śyāma ] śāma (U2)

[ 7. Lotus within the heart]

[VII. Lotus within the Heart] (h07)

The fourth lotus is twelve petalled [and] exists within the heart. The place of the Anāhatacakra is at the heart. The colour is white. The quality is Tamas. The deity is Rudra. The power is Umā. The Ṛṣi is Hiraṇyagarbha.The mount is Nandī. The vitalwind is Prāṇa. The body is the instrument of the digit of light. The state is deep sleep. The speech is Paśyantī. The Veda is Sāma[veda]. The fire is the fire of the householder. The object of veneration is Śiva. The level is attaining.Cf. yogasutra 3.45: ``Attaining is that by which one can touch the moon with the fingertips.'' (prāptir aṅgulyagreṇāpi spṛśati candramasam). The liberation is taking the same form [as the deity]. [There are] twelve petals. [The] twelve [internal] syllables [are]: kaṃ khaṃ gaṃ ghaṃ ṇaṃ caṃ chaṃ jaṃ jhaṃ ñaṃ ṭaṃ ṭhaṃ. The external mother goddesses [are]: Rudrāṇī, Tejasā, Tāpinī, Sukhadā, Caitanyā, Śivadā, Śānti, Umā, Gaurī, Mātarā, Jvalā [and] Prajvālinī. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palas. Because of being made of [such an] intense light, [the fourth lotus] is not in the range of sight. In its middle exists an eight petalled lotus facing downwards. The mind resides in the cakra. The deity is Manas. The power is Bahi.Bahiśśaktiḥ is the external energy that permeates the external space. The conjecture is based on kriyakrama (Ed. p. 96) and sakalagama quoted with reference siddhāntaśekhare (Ed. p. 80): caraṇāṅguṣṭhayor yugmāt sañcintya suṣirāntanau | suṣirāntabahiśśaktiṃ vyāpinīṃ cintayet tataḥ ||. The Ṛṣi is the self. In the middle of the heartI conjectured nābhi° to hṛdaya° since the context is an eight petalled lotus whose eight petals are discussed in englishU 2 . is a lotus whose stalk is ten fingers long. Its stalk is soft. [The lotus] is pure [and] facing downwards. There is [something] resembling a banana flower established within it. The mind wants advancement, but its essence is indecision. While the mind rests on the eastern petal, which is white, a clear intellect endowed with the fame of dharma, knowledge, etc., arises. While in the southeast, which is reddish, a mind endowed with weakness, illusion, sleepiness, and laziness arises. While in the right south, being black, the production of anger arises. While in the southwest, which is blue, a mind of selfishness arises. While in the west, which is brown, a mind [focussed on] play, laughter, and excitement arise. While in the northwest, which is dark in colour, a mind endowed with worry and anxiety arises.

uttare pītavarṇe bhogaśṛṅgāramahodayamatir bhavati/ jñānasaṃdhānamatir bhavati/= Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 3 4): ta ca prāṇavāyoḥ sthānam | aṣṭadalakamalamadhye liṃgākārā karṇikācf. YSv (PT p. 832): prāṇavāyoḥ sthalañcāsya liṅgākāran tu karṇikā | kālikākhyā karṇikeyaṃ asyā madhye tu kuṇḍalī |tanmadhye prāṇavāyoḥ sthānam aṣṭadalakamalamadhye liṃgākārā karṇikā kathyate/ = Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 4): kaliketi saṃjñikāsti tanmadhye padmarāgaratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā puttalikācf. YSv (PT p. 832): padmavatyāḥ (padmāvatyāḥ YK 1.259) prabhāṅguṣṭhapramāṇā (°prāmāṇa° YK 1.259) ratnasannibhā | tasyā saṅgī (tasya saṅgī YK 1.260) jīva iti ananto balarūpataḥ | asya dhyānaṃ (dhyānād YK 1.260) jagadvaśyaṃ khecarīsarvago bhavet | bhavanti vaśyā devādyāś cintākarttur na (citta° YK 1.260) cānyathā | iṣṭāniṣṭo (iṣṭāniṣṭa YK 1.261) bhaved vaśyaḥ (vaśyaṃ YK 1.261) satyaṃ satyaṃ na saṃśayaḥ | iṣṭasiddhir bhavet tasya sarvajñādiguṇodayaḥ |tasyāḥ kaliketi saṃjñā/ tatkalikāmadhye padmarāgaratnasamānavarṇāṅguṣṭhapramāṇaikā puttalikā vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 5): jīveti saṃjñikāsti | tasyāḥ balaṃ svarūpaṃ ca koṭijihvābhir vaktuṃ na śakyaṃ ||tasyā jīveti saṃjñā/ tasyā balaṃ atha ca svarūpaṃ koṭijihvābhir vaktuṃ na śakyate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 5 6): asyā mūrtter dhyānakaraṇāt sādhakasya svargapātāla ākāśagaṃdharvakiṃnaraguhyakavidyādharastrīyo vaśā bhavati |asyā mūrter dhyānakāraṇāt svargapātālākāśamanuṣyagandharvakinnaraguhyakavidyādharalokasaṃbandhinyāḥ strīyaḥ sādhakasya puruṣasya vaśyā bhavanti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 6 7): pṛthvī loke manuṣyādi striṇāṃ kākathā cha |ity atra kiṃ kathyate// (p07_01)

jñānasaṃdhāna ] jñānasaṃdhāne (U2)
vāyoḥ (ceteri) ] °vāyo (U1 U2)
karṇikā (ceteri) ] karṇi (U2)
kaliketi (ceteri) ] kalikeli (L), karṇiketi (E)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] om. (L)
tatkalikāmadhye (ceteri) ] tataḥ (N2), om. (L)
rāgaratnasamānavarṇāṅguṣṭhapramāṇaikā ] °rāgasamānavarṇāṃguṣṭhapramāṇaikā (E), °ratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā (L), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇāṃ || aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā || ekā (P N1), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇa aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā (N2), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇāt ekā (D U1)
tasyā (E P) ] tasyāḥ (X), tasya (L U2)
jīveti saṃjñā (N1) ] jīveti saṃjñaḥ || (N2), jīveti saṃjña | (D), jīvasaṃjñā || (Y), om. (L)
tasyā (E N2 P) ] tasyāḥ (D N1 U1), tasya (U2)
balaṃ atha ca svarūpaṃ (ceteri) ] balamadhyasvarūpaṃ (E), bala sappa svarūpaṃ (L), balam atha svarūpaṃ (P), balaṃ tasya atha svarūpaṃ (U2)
koṭijihvābhir va (ceteri) ] koṭijihvāyābhi (L)
na (ceteri) ] naiva (E P)
asyā (ceteri) ] asyāḥ (N1 D U1), tasyāḥ (U2)
mūrter dhyā (ceteri) ] mūrtir (L N2)
nakāraṇāt sva (ceteri) ] dhyānaṃ karaṇāt || (U2), dhyānāt (L)
pātālākāśa (Y) ] °pātāla ākāśa° (X)
saṃbandhinyāḥ ] °saṃbandhinyāḥ (E L P X), saṃdadhinya (U2)
strīyaḥ sādhakasya puruṣasya (X) ] strīyo 'pi (E P L), striyo pi (U2)
vaśyā bhavanti (ceteri) ] vaśyo bhavati (N2)
kiṃ (X) ] om. (Y)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathyate vā (U1)
While in the north, which is yellow, a mind occupied with enjoyment, sexual passion, and prosperity arises. While in the northeast, which is whitish, a mind united with gnosis arises. It is said that in its middle is the place of the prāṇa vitalwind [and] in the middle [of] the eight petalled lotus is a central receptacle (karṇikā)Regarding the translating karṇikā as ``central receptacle'' instead the most common translation ``pericarp'', see reigle2012. in the form of a liṅga. The technical designation of it is bud (kalikā).A similar concept, including the usage of the term kalikā, is found in the chapter on creation (sargakāṇḍa) of the ramatosana. In a quotation attributed to a text called Śāktānanda, the jīva is described as having the shape of a bud of light (pradīpakalikākāro jīvo) and always resides in the heart. (ādau sañjāyate bījaṃ brahmāṇḍaṃ sahasāṅkuraḥ | tasya madhye sumeruś ca kaṅkāladaṇḍarūpadhṛk | carācarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ devādīnāṃ viśeṣataḥ | ālayaḥ savabhūtānāṃ meror abhyantare 'pi ca | pradīpakalikākāro jīvo hṛdi sadā sthitaḥ |). In the middle of this bud exists a single thumb sized [divine] figurine (puttalikā)The concept of a puttalikā in the heart can be traced back to the Kaula Tantras, e.g., the saradaavalon 22.126 128: (puttalikāyā hṛdayaṃ spṛśan prāṇā iha prāṇā jīva iha sthita iti indriyāṇi spṛśan sarvendriyāṇi vāṅmanaścakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇeti sarvāṅgaṃ spṛśan prāṇā ihāyāntu sukhaṃ ciraṃ tiṣṭhan tu iti śiraḥ spṛśan svāheti japet | mantranyāsam iti |). being similar to a ruby gem in color. Her technical designation is Jīva.The idea of the thumb sized soul residing in the heart is already present in the oldest strata of yogic literature. See kathaup 6.17 (aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo 'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ | taṃ svāc charīrāt pravṛhen muñjād iveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa | taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtaṃ taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtam iti ||17||). Also cf. hauschild1927 3.13. Not even with ten million tongues is it possible to talk about her nature and her power. As a result of meditation on this form the women of the inhabitants of the world [which are] Humans, Gandharvas, Kinnaras, Guhyakas, Vidyādharas, in the heavenly world, underworld, and open space become obedient to the will of the practicing person. [This] is what is said here. \flushpage

[ 8. kaṇṭhasthāne kamalam]

[VIII. kaṇṭhasthāne kamalam] (h08)

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 7): kaṃṭhasthāne paṃcamaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ viśudhhasaṃjñakaṃ cakraṃ varttate ||cf. YSv (PT p. 832) = YK 1.262: kalāpatraṃ pañcaman tu viśuddhaṃ kaṇṭhadeśataḥ |cf. SSP 2.5 (Ed. pp. 30 31): pañcamaṃ kaṇṭhacakraṃ caturaṅgulam | tatra vāma iḍā candranāḍī | dakṣiṇe piṅgalā sūryanāḍī | tanmadhye suṣumnāṃ dhyāyet | saiva anāhatakalā anāhatasiddhidā bhavati |idānīṃ pañcamaṃ kamalaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne vartate/ dhūmravarṇam// jīvo devatā// avidyā śaktiḥ// virāṭ ṛṣiḥ// vāyur vāhanam// udānavāyuḥ// jvālā kalā// jālandharo bandhaḥ// mahākāraṇadehaḥ// tūryāvasthā// parāvācā// atharvaṇavedaḥ// jaṅgamaliṅgam// jīvaprāptā bhūmikā// sāyujyatā mokṣaḥ// ṣoḍaśadalāni// ṣoḍaśa// mātṛkāḥ antarmātṛkāḥ// aṃ āṃ iṃ īṃ uṃ ūṃ ṛṃ ṝṃ ḷṃ ḹṃ eṃ aiṃ oṃ auṃ aṃ aṃḥ// bahirmātṛkāḥ// vidyā// avidyā// icchā// śaktiḥ// jñānaśaktiḥ// śatalā// mahāvidyā// mahāmāyā// buddhiḥ// tāmasī// maitrā// kumārī// maitrāyaṇī// rudrā// puṣṭā// siṃhanī// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000// gha. 2 pa. 46 akṣara 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 7 8): tatra koṭicaṃdraprabha ekaḥ puruṣo stitanmadhye koṭicandrasamaprabhaḥ ekaḥ puruṣo vartate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 832) = YK 1.262: asya madhye pumān ekaḥ koṭicandrasamaprabhaḥ | naśyantya sādhyarogā hi sahasrāyuś ca cintanāt |= Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 8): tasya puruṣasya dhyānakaraṇād asādhyarogā naśyaṃti ||tasya puruṣasya dhyānakaraṇād asādhyarogā naśyanti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 8): sahasravarṣaṃ jīvati |ekasahasravarṣaparyantaṃ puruṣo jīvati// (p08_01)

idānīṃ (X) ] om. (Y)
kamalaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne (D N1 U1) ] kamalaṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne (N2), kaṇṭhasthāne ṣoḍaśadalaṃ kamalaṃ (E P L), viśuddhacakraṃ kaṃṭhastāne (U2)
dhūmravarṇam ] dhūmravarṇe (U2)
virāṭ ṛ ] virāṭha (U2)
mahākāraṇadehaḥ ] mahākāraṇadeha (U2)
mātṛkāḥ ] °mātrāḥ (U2)
antarmātṛkāḥ ] antarmātrār carāḥ (U2)
uṃ ] u (U2)
bahirmātṛkāḥ ] bahirmātrā (U2)
icchā ] ichā (U2)
śaktiḥ ] śakti (U2)
tāmasī ] tamasī (U2)
puṣṭā ] puṣṭa° (U2)
ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ ] ajapājapasahasra (U2)
samaprabhaḥ (ceteri) ] °samaprabhaḥ || (U2), °samaprabhā (L D), °sūryasamāna (E)
ekaḥ puruṣo (ceteri) ] ekapuruṣo (D), eka pumān (U2)
puruṣasya (ceteri) ] puṃsaḥ (U2)
dhyānakaraṇād a (ceteri) ] dhyānakaraṇāt (N1 N2), dhyānakaraṇāt | (D U1 U2)
paryantaṃ (ceteri) ] °paryaṃta (N2), om. (L)
puruṣo (ceteri) ] sa puruṣo (E P)
jīvati (ceteri) ] jīvati |cha| (U1), jīvatīdānīṃ (E)

[ 8. Lotus within the location of the throat]

[VIII. Lotus within the location of the throat] (h08)

\indent Now, the fifth sixteen petalled lotus exists at the location of the throat. The color is grey. The deity is Jīva. The power is ignorance. The Ṛṣi is Virāṭa. The mount is the vitalwind. The vitalwind is Udāna. The digit is the flame. The lock is Jālandhara. The body is the primordial cause (mahākāraṇa). The state is the fourth state (tūrya). The speech is Parā. The Veda is Atharvaṇa[veda]. The object of veneration is the movable. The level is Jīvaprāptā. The liberation is the union with the deity (sāyujyatā). [Associated with it are] sixteen petals [and] sixteen mātṛkas. The internal syllables [are]: aṃ āṃ iṃ īṃ u ūṃ ṛṃ ṝṃ ḷṃ ḹṃ eṃ aiṃ oṃ auṃ aṃ aṃḥ. The external mother goddesses [are]: Vidyā, Avidyā, Icchā, Śakti, Jñānaśakti, Śatalā, Mahāvidyā, Mahāmayā, Buddhi, Tāmasī, Maitrā, Kumārī, Maitrāyaṇī, Rudrā, Puṣṭā, Siṃhanī. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palas. 40 akṣaras. In its middle exists the one consciousness shining like a thousand moons. As a result of meditation on this consciousness, incurable diseases vanish. The person lives up to 1001 years. \flushpage

[ 9. ājñācakram]

[IX. ājñācakram] (h03)

\linenumbers

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): ājñākhyaṃ ṣaṣṭhakaṃ (ṣaṭkaṃ YK 1.264) cakraṃ bhruvor madhye dvipatrakam | agnijvālānibhaṃ jyotiḥ puṃsaḥ strīto (pūṃsastrīto YK 1.264) vivarjitam | dhyānāc cāsya sarvasiddhirajarāmaratāṃ vrajet |Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 8 9): bhrūvor madhye dvidalaṃ ājñācakraṃ ṣaṣṭhaṃ |cf. SSP 2.7 (Ed. p. 31): saptamaṃ bhrūcakraṃ madhyamāṅguṣṭhamatram | tatra jñānanetraṃ dīpaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra vāksiddhir bhavati |idānīṃ ṣaṣṭhacakraṃ ājñānāmakaṃ vartate/ agnir devatā// suṣumṇā śaktiḥ// haṃsa ṛṣiḥ// caitanyavāhanaṃ// jñānadehaḥ// vijñānāvasthā// anupamavācā// sāmavedaḥ// pramādaliṅgaṃ// ardhamātrā// ākāśatattvam// jīvo haṃsaḥ// caitanyalīlā āraṃbhaḥ// dve mātṛke// haṃ kṣaṃ// antar mātṛke bahir mātṛke sthitiḥ// prabhā// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000// gha. 2 pa. 46 akṣara 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 9): gnijvālākāraṃ paramātmasaṃjñakaṃ vastv āsti |tac cakraṃ bhruvor madhye dvidalakaṃ sthitaṃ/ tanmadhye'gnijvālākāram akalaṃ kiṃcid vastu vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 9 10): tac ca na strīpumān | tasya dhyānakaraṇād ajarāmaraḥ sādhako bhavati |cha|na strī na pumān/ tasya dhyānakaraṇāt puruṣasya śarīram ajarāmaraṃ bhavati// (p09_01)

ṣaṣṭhacakraṃ (X) ] ṣaṣṭhaṃ bhrūmadhye (E P), ṣaṣṭhaḥ bhrūmadhye (L), ṣaṣṭa bhrūmadhye (U2)

vartate (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
agnir de ] āgnir (U2)

ākāśa ] ākāśā (U2)

līlā āraṃbhaḥ ] °līlāraṃbhaḥ (U2)

Witness B starts here.

[ 9. Ājñācakra]

[IX. Ājñācakra] (h09)

Now, a sixth cakra named Ājñā exists.SSP 2.7 declares this cakra to be thumb sized, and calls it the eye of wisdom (jñānanetram) onto which the practitioner shall meditate upon as a flame of a lamp with the result of achieving the perfection of speech (saptamaṃ bhrūcakraṃ madhyamāṅguṣṭhamatram | tatra jñānanetraṃ dīpaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra vāksiddhir bhavati |). The deity is fire. The power is the central channel. The Ṛṣi is Haṃsa. The mount is consciousness. The body is knowledge. The state is insight. The speech is the incomparable (anupama). The Veda is Sāma[veda]. The object of veneration is intoxication. [It is consisting of] half a measure. It is hard to make sense of ardhamātrā. My best hunch is that an ardha divides something into two. It might be meant as a synonym hinting at to the two mātṛkas that follow. The principle is space. The gander is the living soul. The origin is the activity of consciousness. There are two māṭrkas. The inner syllables [are]: haṃ [and] kṣam. The external mother goddesses [are]: Sthiti [and] Prabhā. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palas, and 40 akṣaras. This two petalled cakra is located in the middle of the eyebrows. In its middle exists a certain object in the form of a blazing fire without parts. [It is] not female, [it is] not male. As a result of meditation on it, the body of the person becomes non aging and immortal. \flushpage

[ 10. cakraṃ tālumadhye]

[X. cakraṃ tālumadhye] (h10)

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 10): tālumadhye catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ amṛtapūrṇaṃcf. YSv (PT pp. 832 833): catuḥṣaṣṭidalaṃ tālumadhye cakran tu madhyamam | pīyūṣapūrṇaṃ (pīyūṣapūrṇa° YK 1.266) koṭīndusannibhaṃ (°sannibha° YK 1.266) cāmṛtasthalī | tanmadhye ghaṭikāsaṃjñā karṇikā raktasannibhā | saha cendukalā tatrāmṛtadhārāṃ (tāndrā° YK 1.267) sravaty asau | etad dhyātvāmṛtaiḥ snātvā sadā yogāt pramucyate |idānīṃ saptamaṃ cakraṃ catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ tālumadhye'mṛtapūrṇaṃ vartate/ lalāṭamaṇḍalam// candro devatā// amṛtā śaktiḥ// paramātmā ṛṣiḥ// amṛtavāsinīkalā saptadaśī// amṛtakallolanadī// mahākāśā// aṃbikā// laṃbikā// ghaṇṭikā// tālikā// ajapāgāyatrīdehasvarūpam// kākamukhī// naranetrā// gośṛṅgālalāṭā// brahmapaṭhā// hayagrīvā// mayūramukhā// haṃsavad aṅgāni// ajapāgāyatrīsvarūpam// (p10_01)

cakraṃ catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ tālumadhye (X) ] tālumadhye catuḥṣaṣṭidalaṃ (E P U2), tāludeśe madhye catuḥṣaṣṭhidala (L B)
'mṛtapūrṇaṃ ] amṛtapūrṇaṃ (ceteri), amṛtapūrṇa (N2)
mahākāśā ] mahākāśa (U2)
dehasvarūpam ] dehasvarūpaṃ (U2)
lalāṭā ] lalāṭa (U2)
svarūpam ] svarūpaṃ (U2)

[ 10. Cakra within the palate]

[X. Cakra within the palate] (h10)

Now, the seventh cakra, having sixty four petals [and] being full of nectar, exists in the middle of the palate.The cakra at the palate is located after the ājñācakra between the eyebrows, deviating from the typical ascending order. Rāmacandra adopts this sequence from the Yogasvarodaya, in contrast to other ninefold cakra systems. For details, see table 19 in shivayogapradipika. Rāmacandra revises this order in section 29 on page , borrowing from the SSP, which prioritizes the tālucakra before the ājñācakra. The Maṇḍala is the forehead. The deity is the moon. The power is the nectar of immortality. The Ṛṣi is the supreme self. [It is] the river with waves of nectar. [It is] the seventeenth digit. [It is] the residence of the nectar of immortality. [It is] the great space. [It is] the ``little mum''The terms aṃbikā, laṃbikā, ghaṇṭikā, and tālikā may refer to the uvula. In the jogpradipyaka, a haṭhayogic practice called manthana ( mallinson2010) describes two variations. The second type (vv. 643 653) instructs the yogin to use a metal peg (kīla dhātamaya) to churn, purify, and produce amī (= amṛta) at four locations: ambikā (frenum), lambikā (tongue), tālu (palate), and ghaṇṭikā (uvula). These places correspond to the teats of Kāmadhenu, the ``wish fulfilling cow'' (v. 651). The Vairaṭapurāṇa locates an amṛtacakra at the forehead emitting ``nectar''. This is the dwelling place of Gāyatrī known as Kāmadhenu, with four teats: Ambikā, Lambikā, Ghaṇṭikā, and Tālikā ( kaviraj). [It is] the uvula. [It is] the TālikāThe precise meaning of tālikā is unclear. In a private discussion, mallinson2014b suggested it might originate from tālu.. [It is] the ``little bell''. The nature of the body of the unspeakable GāyatrīTantric mantras are frequently associated with a deity and their bodies, cf. haasgayatri. [is]: the beak of a crow, the eye[s] of a humanThe concept of ``human eyes'' is probably here to emphasize the contrast with the traditional notion of crows possessing only a single eye. I want to thank Dr. Dominic A. haasgayatri for this note., a forehead with the horn[s] of a cow, the recitation is the Brahman,Possibly the Veda or any sacred word, like i.e. the sacred syllable oṃ or speculatively even the ajapā gāyatrī itself. However, it is unclear whether the haṃsa mantra is considered a Vedic Brahman. I am grateful for Dr. Dominic A. haasgayatri suggestions regarding this passage., a neck like a horse, the face of a peacock [and] limbs of a swan. [This is] the own form of the unspeakable Gayatrī.The bird like body of the ajapā gāyatrī seems to refer to the body of a specific haṃsa (``swan'') as the ajapā gayatrī contains \ldots \flushpage

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 11): adhikataraśobhayuktaṃ atiśvetaṃ cakraṃ | tanmadhye raktavarṇaghaṃṭikāsaṃjñā varttate |adhikataraśobhayuktam// atiśvetam // tanmadhye raktavarṇaṃ ghaṇṭikāsaṃjñā ekā karṇikā vartate/ tanmadhye bhūmiḥ/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 11 2r. l.1): tanmadhye prakaṭacandrakalā amṛtādhārāsravaṃtī varttate |tanmadhye'prakaṭacandrakalā amṛtadhārāsravantī vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 1): tasyāḥ kalāyā nirantaraṃ dhyānakartum maraṇaṃtasyāḥ kalāyā dhyānakaraṇāt tasya samīpe maraṇaṃ nāyāti/ nirantaradhyānakaraṇād amṛtadhārā sravati/ cf. YSv (PT p. 833): unmādajvarapittādidāhaśūlādivedanāḥ (°śūnyā° YK 1.268) | naśyanti ca śiroduḥkhaṃ jāḍyabhāvo 'pi naśyati | sadyodhyānādbhuktaviśvaṃ jihvājāḍyañ ca naśyati (last sentence om.in YK) \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 1 2): kṣayarogaḥ pettajvarahṛdayadāhaśiro..jihvāyājaḍyaṃ ca naśyati |tadā kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvā naśyanti/ bhakṣitaṃ viṣam api na bādhate/ yadyatra manaḥ sthiraṃ bhavati// (p10_02)

kataraśobhayuktam (ceteri) ] °kataraśobhāyuktaṃ (N2), °kaśobhāyuktam (E), °kataraprabhāmuktaṃ (U2)
atiśvetam ] atiśvetaṃ (U2)
raktavarṇaṃ (ceteri) ] raktavarṇa° (N2)
ghaṇṭikā (ceteri) ] ghāṃṭikā° (E), ghaṭikā° (P), ghaṇikā° (L)
ekā (ceteri) ] ekā ekā (L B)
bhūmiḥ (ceteri) ] bhūmis° (U1), bhūmi (U2)
'prakaṭa (ceteri) ] pragaṭa (U1), °ṃdrakaṭaṃ (U2)
amṛtadhārāsravantī (ceteri) ] 'mṛtādhārā sravaṃti (L B), 'mṛtādhārā sravati (P U2), 'mṛtādhārā bhavati (E)
vartate (X) ] om. (Y)
kalāyā (ceteri) ] kalāyāḥ (N1 N2 U1), karṇikāyā (L B)
nāyāti (ceteri) ] na yāti (L B U2)
dhyānakaraṇā (ceteri) ] °dhyānād (E P)
d amṛtadhārā (ceteri) ] amṛtadhārāyāḥ sajīvo (E), amṛtadhārā plāvanaṃ (P), amṛtadhārā plavanaṃ (U2)
sravati (L B U1) ] sravaṃti (N1 N2 D), bhavati (E P U2)
tadā (Y) ] om. (X)
kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvā ] yakṣamarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvā (E), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvān (P), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāharogajihvāyājaḍabhāvān (L), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāharogajihvāyājaḍavān (B), kṣayarogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (N1), kṣayarogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvātā (N2), kṣayaṃ rogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (D), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (U1), kṣayarogoptatti || jvara hṛdayadāha || śiroroga || jihvājaḍatā || dayo (U2)
bhakṣitaṃ (N2 U1) ] bhakṣitam (N1), bhakṣitāṃ (D), bhakṣitam api (E P L U2), bhākṣitamār pi (B)
viṣam api (X) ] viṣaṃ (B L U2), viṣan (E), viṃṣa (P)
bādhate (E P N2) ] bādhyate (ceteri)
yadyatra (ceteri) ] yady atram api (B L), yady anna (D N1)
manaḥ sthiraṃ (E P) ] manasthiraṃ (ceteri)
2.2emthe unrecited [a]haṃ sa "I am that" expression. The haṃsa is a common metaphor for the soul wandering in the wheel of Brahman or Saṃsāra. Cf. hauschild1927 1.6 and 3.18. The animal body parts perhaps symbolize the various physical embodiments the jīva undergoes while traversing the brahmacakra. As noted by haasgayatri, while the association between the Vedic Gāyatrī and birds was once prominent in Vedic literature, it seems to have diminished. However, here, it survived in the context of the ajapā gāyatrī. [It is] endowed with superabundant beauty. [It is] very bright. In its middle exists a unique central receptacle named ``the little bell'' (ghāṇṭikā)The term ghaṇṭikā, meaning "little bell," commonly denotes the uvula ( mallinson2010, padoux1994). Within the sixfold cakra system of kubji1988 7.85, the uvula serves as a pathway for the ascent of breath, mantra, and self between the fifth and the sixth cakra (lalanāghaṇṭike yojya pañcamaṃ sthānam ākramet | ākramed guhyacakraṃ tu karaṇaṃ cordhvamūlakam ||). being red in colour. In its centre is a site. In the middle of that exists the hidden digit of the moon, which is oozing a stream of nectar. As a result of meditation on this digit, death does not go near him. As a result of uninterrupted meditation, the stream of nectar flows. Then, the states of wasting[ disease] (kṣayaroga)A fever which causes depletion in the body, cf. ayurveda, ayurveda., bilious fever (pittajvara)A fever due to disordered bile, cf. ibid. ayurveda., burning sensation of the heart (hṛdayadāha)The burning sensation in the heart caused by heart disease resulting from disordered bile, cf. ibid. ayurveda., head disease (śiroroga) The term refers to disorders of the head. When blood, fat, phlegm, or vata decreases, it causes severe pain, cf. ibid. ayurveda. and tongue insensibility (jihvājāḍya)Stiffness or numbness of the tongue, cf. ibid. ayurveda. vanish. Even ingested venom does not trouble when the mind becomes stable here. \flushpage

[ 11. aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmarandhrasthāne]

[XI. aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmarandhrasthāne] (h11)

cf. YSv (PT p. 833): brahmarandhre 'ṣṭamaṃ cakraṃ śatapatraṃ mahāprabham |cf. SSP 2.8 (Ed. pp. 31 32): aṣṭamaṃ brahmarandhraṃ nirvāṇacakraṃ sūcikāgrabhedyam |idānīṃ aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmarandhrasthāne śatadalaṃ vartate/ gurudevatā// caitanyaśaktiḥ// virāṭ ṛṣiḥ// sarvotkṛṣṭasākṣiḥ// bhūtaturyātītacaitanyātmakam// sarvavarṇāḥ// sarvamātrāḥ// sarvadalāni// virāṭ dehaḥ// sthitāvasthā// prajñā vācā// sohaṃ vedaḥ// anupamasthānaṃ// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000 ghaṭi 2 palā 46 akṣara 40// sarvajapaḥ saṃkhyā// 21600// ekaviṃśatisahasrāṇiṣaṭśatāni// tathaiva ca niśāhe vahate// prāṇaṃ yo jānāti sa paṇḍitaḥ// (p11_01)

aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmarandhrasthāne śatadalaṃ (D N1 N2) ] cakraṃ brahmaraṃdhrasthāne śatadalaṃ (U1), brahmarandhrasthāne 'ṣṭamaṃ śatadalaṃ cakraṃ (E P U2), brahmaraṃdhrasthāne aṣṭamaṃ śatadalaṃ cakraṃ (B L)
dehaḥ ] deha (U2)
vedaḥ ] veda (U2)
ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ ] ajapājapasahasra (U2)
sarvajapaḥ ] sarvajapa° (U2)
prāṇaṃ ] prāṇaḥ (U2)

\approx vivekamartandaolda 29: hakāreṇa bahir yāti sakāreṇa viśaty adhaḥ | haṃsa haṃsety amuṃ mantraṃ jīvo japati sarvadā || \approx yogabija 106: hakāreṇa bahir yāti sakāreṇa viśen marut | haṃsa haṃseti mantro 'yaṃ sarvajīvā japanti vai || quoted with reference (yogabīje) \approx yogacintamanilahore (f. 6r): sakāreṇa bahir yāti hakāreṇa viśen marut | haṃsa haṃseti amum mantraṃ jīvo japanti sarvadā || quoted with reference (yogabīje) \approx hathatattvakaumudi 22.27: hakāreṇa bahir yāti sakāreṇa viśet punaḥ | haṃsa haṃseti mantro'yaṃ sarve jīvā japanti vai || \approx yogasikhopanisad 1.130cd 131ab (Ed. p. 416): hakāreṇa bahir yāti sakāreṇa viśet punaḥ | haṃsa haṃseti mantro'yaṃ sarvair jīvaiś ca japyate || sakāreṇa bahir yāti hakāreṇa viśet punaḥ/ haṃsaḥ so'haṃ tato mantraṃ jīvo japati sarvadā// 11.1 // 11_2

[ 11. Eighth cakra at the aperture of brahman]

[XI. Eighth cakra at the aperture of brahman] (h11)

Now, [there] exists the eighth cakra having one hundred petals at the location of the aperture of Brahman.The brahmarandhra, often termed the "aperture of Brahman," is a tiny opening at the crown near the fontanelle. Its name originates from ancient Upaniṣadic beliefs, portraying it as a portal for the individual soul (ātman) to surpass bodily limitations and merge with the absolute (brahman). The deity is the teacher. The power is consciousness. The Ṛṣi is Virāṭ. [It is] the witness above everything. The nature of consciousness is the state beyond the fourth state. [It has] all colors. [It has] all mātrāsThis could refer either to syllables, mother goddesses or both.. [It has] all petals. The body is Virāṭ. The state is steadyPossibly in the sense of cessation.. The speech is wisdom. The Veda is the "I am that" [expression] (so'haṃ). The place is unsurpassed. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palas, 40 akṣaras. The count of all mutterings [per day] is 21600. In this way, it carries on day and night. He who knows the breath is a learned person. 11.1 With the sound ``sa'', he exhales. With the sound ``ha'', he inhales again: ``I am he, he is I''. Because of that, the embodied soul constantly utters the Mantra. \flushpage

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 2 3): brahmaraṃdhre śatadalaṃ jālaṃdharapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ siddhapuruṣasyānacakraṃcf. YSv (PT p. 833): jālandharaṃ nāma pīṭhaṃ etat tu parikīrttitam | siddhapuṃsaḥ (°puṃsa° YK 1.270) sthalaṃ jñātvā agnidhūmanibhā śikhā | ādimadhyāntahīnā strīpuṃmūrtti (°mūrtir YK 1.270) varttate parā | antajñānī (antaryāmī YK 1.271) bhaved dhyānād ākāśe 'pi samāgamaḥ | nirantaraṃ sarvavettā ity ūccāno mahān bhavet | jaganmadhye sthito jantur jagadbādhāvivarjitaḥ |cf. SSP 2.8 (Ed. pp. 31 32): tatra dhūmaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra jālandharapīṭhaṃ mokṣapradaṃ bhavati |tasya kamalasya jālandharapīṭha iti saṃjñā/ siddhapuruṣasya sthānaṃ/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 3): tanmadhye gnidhūmrāreṣākārā ādimadhyaṃtarahitā puruṣasya mūrttir asti |tanmadhye'gnidhūmākārā rekhā yādṛśī/ tādṛśy ekā puruṣasya mūrtir vartate/ tasyā nādir nānto'sti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 4): tasyāḥ dhyānakartuḥtasyā mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt pratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ puruṣasyākāśe gamāgamau bhavataḥ/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 4 5): pṛthivyāṃ sthitāv api pṛthvī kṛtabādho na bhavati | trikālikajñānaṃ pratyakṣaṃ bhavati | āyurvṛddiḥ liṃgaśarīreṇa sarvatra pratyakṣaṃ gamāgamo bhavati |pṛthvīmadhye sthitasyāpi pṛthvībādho na bhavati/ sakalaṃ pratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ paśyati pṛthagbhavati/ atiśayenāyur vardhate// (p11_02)

kamalasya (ceteri) ] kamala° (E)
jālandharapīṭha (ceteri) ] jālandharapīṭha° (B), jātyadharaṇīpīṭha (E)
iti (ceteri) ] om. (B)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] °saṃjñā (B)

tasyā (Y) ] tasyāḥ (X)

puruṣasyākāśe (ceteri) ] puruṣa ākāśe (N2), puruṣasyākāśa° (U2), puruṣasya ākāśi (U1)
gamau (ceteri) ] °gamo (U1), °game (N2)
bhavataḥ (ceteri) ] bhavata (U2)
pṛthvīmadhye (ceteri) ] pṛtivīmadhye (B U2)
sthitasyāpi (ceteri) ] sthitāv api (Y)
pṛthvībādho (E L) ] pṛtvībādho (B), pṛthaka (P), pṛthvī bādhoko (U2), pṛthvī kṣato bādho (X)
na bhavati (ceteri) ] bhavati (P)
sakalaṃ pratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ ] sakalāpratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ (X), sakalāḥ pratyakṣaṃ niraṃtara (B L), sakalān pratyakṣaṃ niraṃtaraṃ (E), om. (P U2)
paśyati (ceteri) ] paśyatī (L B), om. (P U2)
pṛthagbhavati (E) ] ca pṛthak bhavati (B L), ca pṛthak ca bhavati (N1 N2 U1), ca pṛthak pṛthak bhavati (D), om. (P U2)
atiśayenāyur va (E P) ] atīśayanāyur (B L), atiśayena āyur (X), om. (U2)
rdhate (ceteri) ] vardhayate (B L)
``The seat of Jālandhara'' is the name of its lotus.Cf. the description of the eigth cakra in saubhagya and ssplonavla 2.8. [It is] the place of the accomplished person. In middle of it, there is a streak looking like the manifestation of smoke and fire, and in such a way, the unique manifestation of consciousness exists. It has no end nor a beginning. As a result of meditation on the manifestation, direct perception of both the coming and going of the soul in space arises. Affliction from the earth element does not arise [anymore] even if one is within the earth. One constantly sees everything direct [and] one becomes seperateProbably from the rest of matter in the sense of Sāṃkhya.. The span of life increases greatly. \flushpage

[ 12. mahāśūnyacakram]

[XII. mahāśūnyacakram] (h12)

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 6 11): brahmaraṃdhre eva śatadalacakropari mahāśūnyacakraṃ mahāsiddhacakraṃ pūrṇagiricakraṃ iti saṃjñakaṃ sahasradalaṃ cakraṃ asti | tad upari kiṃcin nāsti | tac cakraṃ atiraktaṃ ūrdhvamukhaṃ sakalaśobhāspadaṃ anekakalyāṇapūrṇaṃ mano vācām agocara parimalo petaṃ |cf. YSv (PT p. 833): navaman tu mahāśūnyaṃ cakran tu tatparātparam | tad upari paraṃ kiñcin nāsti kiñcin mahāparam | mahācakraṃ siddhacakraṃ pūrṇagauryādisaṃjñakam | tanmadhye varttate padmaṃ sahasradalam adbhutam |cf. SSP 2.9 (Ed. pp. 32): navamam ākāśacakraṃ soḍaśadalakamalam ūrdhvamukham | tanmadhye karṇikāyāṃ trikūṭākārāṃ tad ūrdhvaśaktiṃ tāṃ paramaśunyāṃ dhyāyet | tatraiva pūrṇagiripīṭhaṃ sarveṣṭasiddhipradaṃ bhavati |idānīṃ navamacakrasya bhedāḥ kathyante/ tasya mahāśūnyacakram iti saṃjñā/ tad upary aparaṃ kimapi nāsti/ tad eva mahāsiddhacakraṃ kathyate/ tasya pūrṇagiripīṭham iti etādṛśaṃ nāma/ tasya mahāśūnyacakrasya madhye ūrdhvamukham atiraktavarṇaṃ sakalaśobhāspadaṃ anekakalyāṇapūrṇaṃ sahasradalaṃ ekaṃ kamalaṃ vartate cf. YSv (PT p. 833): ūrddhvavakraṃ mahāvaktre (mahāvaktraṃ YK 1.274) varṇaśobhāpadaṃ mahat | sarvakalyāṇasampūrṇamasya tulyaṃ na vidyate | parimāṇaṃ vaktam (vaktum YK 1.275) asya manasā vacasā na hi | trikoṇakarṇikā tatra (°tantraṃ YK 1.276) varttate jagad īśvari | kalā saptadaśī tatra varttate parameśvari | nirañjanakalā sā tu koṭisūryasamaprabhā | koṭicandraprabhā caiva śītoṣṇādivivarjitā | asya dhyānāt sādhakasya manoduḥkhaṃ bhaven na hi | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 9 11): tat kamalamadhye trikoṇākarṇikā | tasyāṃ karṇikāyāṃ saptadaśī niraṃjanarūpā koṭisūryaprabhā satī uṣṇabhava hīnā koṭicandrasamasītalaikākalāsti | tasyāṃ anaṃta paramānaṃtaparamānaṃdānāṃ sthānaṃ tasyāḥ kalāyā dhyānakaraṇāt sādako yadyādi śati tatra bhavati|yasya parimalo manaso vacaso cāgocaraḥ tasya kamalasya madhye trikoṇarūpaikā karṇikā vartate/ tatkarṇikāmadhye saptadaśī ekā nirañjanarūpā kalā varttate/ koṭisūryasamaprabhaṃ kalāyās tejo vartate/ param uṣṇabhāvo nāsti/ koṭicandrasamaprabhaṃ śītalaṃ paraṃ śītabhāvo nāsti/ (p12_01)

navama (ceteri) ] navamaṃ (B), navamaś° (U1)
bhedāḥ (ceteri) ] bheda (N2)
